intro: Prunus serotina f. typica, commonly known as the wild cherry or black cherry, is a deciduous tree native to eastern North America. It typically grows to a height of 10–25 meters, featuring smooth, gray bark and alternate, ovate leaves with serrated edges. The tree produces showy white or pink flowers in spring, followed by small, dark purple berries that ripen in the fall. It thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers moist, well-drained sites and is often found in forested areas.
